Posts.Content: Wanted to give an update on our dilemma when, after 18 mos of zero club post surgery and radiation, the PSA went to 1.7. It was retested a week later and still 1.7, but two doctors were suspicious of that and asked us to go to a different lab. Third test showed 2.53 or almost doubling in a week's time. Not good. Nothing was shown on CT scan or the bone scan so doctor opted for ultrasound around area where prostate had been removed. Still nothing showing so the consensus is that it's in the lymph nodes. From here, nothing looked like an ideal plan. Thanks to all the many, many discussions here and our own research my husband does not want to subject himself to basically chemical castration. His theory is that would add another entire layer of symptoms on top of the actual hormone deprivation. Since he's a heart patient he wants the route easiest for his body. So he's opting for the surgical route. "D" day will be December 29 when the doctor views the results of the next PSA test. Since the original cancer was so aggressive, the odds are that it's still going to be aggressive and fast moving I suppose. We've got lots of people praying but we well know God doesn't always answers prayers like we want. Thus, come December 29, it will be either a miracle cause it's going back down or a date for surgery early January. Any advice from others who've gone this route? Any particular things to be aware of when CA heads to the lymph nodes? Aliza
Posts.Signature: 3/14, age 74: PSA = 19 4/14 Bladder extended grossly; T2; (cancer felt via rectal exam). Catheter inserted 5/14 Needle biopsy; Gleason Grading: 9 Diagnosis: PC; Stage III to Stage IV Aggressive. Treatment recommended: RPP (removal of prostrate) 6/14: PT and CT scans were negative 7/14: RPP pT.3b SV removed; pNX; pMX; Lymph nodes intact; No cath required. UF excellent 9/14- 11/14 SRT (IMRT) 40 treatments 1/15: PSA = < .1, the lowest that Quest Lab uses. 5/15: PSA = < .1 11/15: PSA = 1.7 one week later still 1.7 (my other blood work was so good they thought it may have been mistake) 11/15 Treatment options by radiologist: ADT or take PSA again in six weeks. 11/22 Will meet with urologist re: ADT
Posts.Title: Choosing Orchiectomy over chemical HT

Posts.Content: Greetings to all of you from sunny Florida. First I'd like to say my husband and I are very thankful for all of you who take time to respond to us newbies with your experience and insight, so much learned through your individual trials. We've learned so much just reading. A special double thanks to our moderator HighlanderCFH. I've been bombarding Chuck for several days now with PMs over all the technical problems with the forum and he graciously worked with forum moderators even over the weekend to get us posting. With the technical slowdown our timing is poor since tomorrow is the doctor appointment to discuss HDT options. I'll let my husband speak for himself now. Aliza ____________________________________ When I was 74 we discovered enlarged prostrate was aggressive cancer. Treatments were RPP (7/14)and SRT, 40 treatments (9/14- 11/14). Post radiology and surgery PSAs = .1 (1/15 and 5/15). On 11/4 = 1.7. <sigh> I meet with urologist this week re: HDT. Brain working very well; body not so much. I experience fatigue, bloating, peripheral neuropathy, lumbar pain daily. I walk a mile or two a day. Naps infrequent to frequent. In 2000 diagnosed CAD: six bypasses; two stents and pacemaker since. This March had a major heart attack. A third stent inserted. Blood flow in cardio arteries is good. Heart muscle loss about 10 per cent. Questions: 1) if muscle loss is frequent side effect of HDT, especially with guys my age, wouldn't I lose heart muscle as well? 2) Considering my other non-PC symptoms, would you consider moving forward now or take a wait and see approach? 3) Since original PC was aggressive, does that mean it will always be aggressive and fast moving, since I had 2 virtually zero PSA readings post-surgery and SRT? 4) What are opinions out there re: surgical removal vs. chemical HDT? My present thinking is that going the chemical HDT route, Id be dealing with two types of side effects (chemical and loss of testosterone) while with surgery just the latter.

Catheter inserted 5/14 Needle biopsy; Gleason Grading: 9 Diagnosis: PC; Stage III to Stage IV Aggressive. Treatment recommended: RPP (removal of prostrate) 6/14: PT and CT scans were negative 7/14: RPP pT.3b SV removed; pNX; pMX; Lymph nodes intact; No cath required. UF excellent 9/14- 11/14 SRT (IMRT) 40 treatments 1/15: PSA = < .1, the lowest that Quest Lab uses. 5/15: PSA = < .1 11/15: PSA = 1.7 one week later still 1.7 (my other blood work was so good they thought it may have been mistake) 11/15 Treatment options by radiologist: ADT or take PSA again in six weeks. 11/22 Will meet with urologist re: ADT
Posts.Title: Newbies: HDT questions for tomorrow doctor appointment.

Posts.Content: After being diagnosed with a Gleason of 9.2 in 2014, my urologist, a wonderful surgeon, recommended surgically removing the prostrate, followed by 40 radiation treatments. As a result in January and May of 2015 my PSA was zero. Now the cancer is back and growing rapidly. If my next PSA indicates it, I will undergo an orchioectemy (surgical removal of testes) in January. Here are the reasons I have opted for surgery over drugs. 1. It will be over quickly rather than spread out for months or years. 2. Since I'm a heart patient, drugs put an extra strain on the heart, according to a recent study; 3. I will be dealing only with the side effects of loss of testosterone and not also possible fall out from the drugs; 4. It's cheaper; 5. I'm impressed that it is the procedure of choice in Europe, according to my wife.

Posts.Title: Why I'm opting for HDT surgery over drugs

Posts.Content: I have a friend knowledgeable in the field who told me the gold standard for prostrate cancer is a) Prostatectemy b) Radiation treatments and c) if the cancer isn't held in check, hormone therapy, which means removal of the testes either by drugs or surgery. I have little knowledge of chemo being an important means of treating prostrate cancer.

Posts.Title: PSA rising (38.5 from 5 in 4 weeks)

Posts.Content: Is he in pain? If he is, he needs to locate the best pain management medicine has to offer. I worked in hospice and found they are the gold standard in managing pain. Many assume enrolling in hospice means giving up. Not at all. I've seen many patients in hospice, recover enough to leave hospice and enjoy years of quality and quantity of life. Waiting until the 11th hour to enroll is a tragic mistake. Earlier is better than later. Not only that, the emotional and spiritual support one gets in hospice is second to none. If I find my cancer is causing me difficulties with pain, I'm going to lobby for my doctor to enroll me in hospice. But it won't mean I've given up.

Posts.Title: PSA rising (38.5 from 5 in 4 weeks)

Posts.Content: Pain in the testicles is symptomatic of epididymitis, i.e. infection of the epididymis. I know, because I had it. This painful malady led to prostatitis, i.e. infection of prostrate in my 40's. Since being diagnosed with PC. I've been told prostatits can be a precursor to PC. My urologist back then told me it was bacterial and prescribed five different anti-bacterial medications over three month period. None of his drugs helped. At my fifth visit, I asked him if my infection might be a yeast infection. He told me, rather arrogantly, that men don't get yeast infections and prescribed sulfa drugs which did nothing to eliminate the problem. However, since my wife had some medication in the refrigerator (nystatin) for her serious yeast problem, I began taking the dosage she had taken. My prostatitis was gone in four days. Now I'm going to say something that may sound strange. This is just me. Knowing what I now know about prostratitis and prostrate cancer, back before my cancer diagnosis I would have had a serious discussion with my urologist about the possibility of removing the damned organ, I have two reasons: (1) to vastly reduce my chances of PC, (2) To eliminate all those various, irritating, uncomfortable problems with urination that the prostate gland caused me in later life. Please keep us posted. Wade P.S. a good urologist often can detect irregularities in the prostrate with a digital exam. These irregularities are often associated with PC. My urologist knew I had PC when he did the digital. His biopsies determined the seriousness of it. It was Stage iv, aggressive.

Posts.Title: The "rubber band" stress technique

Posts.Content: While Ron is right that officially the diagnosis isn't fully confirmed until the biopsy, if you have an experienced urologist whose done a ton of digital exams, he can feel the cancer. Mine knew I had cancer, and felt it was serious before the biopsy. The biopsy is necessary. Multiple samples of the prostrate is taken in different locations. I had 12 of them. The results from that was a Gleason rating of 9.something. Then my doc was able to tell me how serious the cancer was, which in my case was aggressive, Stage IV. After surgery to remove the prostrate and radiation, my PSA was zero for six months or so, but now it's up to 2.5 and growing rapidly. If my next PSA continues this way I am opting for surgical removal of testicles rather than by drugs. Studies I read indicate surgical removal is less likely to cause heart issues, and since I had a heart attack last year, It is an outpatient procedure and I will just get it over with in one stroke, rather than spreading it out over time. In Europe surgery is the treatment of choice. It's a small incision and the testes are removed. Prostheses made used to replace the missing organs.

Treatment recommended: RPP (removal of prostrate) 6/14: PT and CT scans were negative 7/14: RPP pT.3b SV removed; pNX; pMX; Lymph nodes intact; No cath required. UF excellent 9/14- 11/14 SRT (IMRT) 40 treatments 1/15: PSA = < .1, the lowest that Quest Lab uses. 5/15: PSA = < .1 11/15: PSA = 1.7 one week later still 1.7 (my other blood work was so good they thought it may have been mistake) 11/15 Treatment options by radiologist: ADT or take PSA again in six weeks. 11/22 Will meet with urologist re: ADT
Posts.Title: Prostate problems for 40 years - new symptoms, cancer questions

Posts.Content: That's the spirit, SU. Every minute we are alive is a gift to be enjoyed. In a song by Irving Berlin (or someone else), "I intend to live, live until I die." Wade
Posts.Signature: 3/14, age 74: PSA = 19 4/14 Bladder extended grossly; T2; (cancer felt via rectal exam). UF excellent 9/14- 11/14 SRT (IMRT) 40 treatments 1/15: PSA = < .1, the lowest that Quest Lab uses. 5/15: PSA = < .1 11/15: PSA = 1.7 one week later still 1.7 (my other blood work was so good they thought it may have been mistake) 11/15 Treatment options by radiologist: ADT or take PSA again in six weeks. 11/22 Will meet with urologist re: ADT
